covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic: For eligible 340B entities listed on the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Health Resources & Service Administration (HRSA) 340B Drug Pricing Program Database, payment shall not exceed the entity's Actual Acquisition Cost for the drug, as charged by the manufacturer at a price consistent with the Veterans Health Care Act of 1992, plus a professional dispensing fee of $10.64.
covered_entities_340B.fcd: When an eligible 340B entity, other than a disproportionate share hospital, a children’s hospital excluded from the Medicare prospective payment system, a free-standing cancer hospital exempt from the Medicare prospective payment system, a sole community hospital, a rural referral center, or a critical access hospital, submits a bill to the Medicaid Agency for a drug purchased by or on behalf of a Medicaid recipient, the amount billed shall not exceed the entity's actual acquisition cost for the drug, as charged by the manufacturer at a price consistent with the Veterans Health Care Act of 1992, plus the dispensing fee established by the Medicaid Agency. A disproportionate share hospital, a children’s hospital excluded from the Medicare prospective payment system, a free-standing cancer hospital exempt from the Medicare prospective payment system, a sole community hospital, a rural referral center, or a critical access hospital may bill Medicaid the total charges for the drug. As manufacturer price changes occur, the entities must ensure that their billings are updated accordingly.

contract_pharmacies_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse 340B contract pharmacies for 340B drugs?
contract_pharmacies_340B.fic:
Payment for covered outpatient drugs (both brand and generic) dispensed by … 340B eligible entities (including 340B contract pharmacies) not listed on the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Health Resources & Service Administration (HRSA) 340B Drug Pricing Program Database … shall not exceed the lowest of:

  • The Alabama Average Acquisition Cost (AAC) of the drug, or when no AAC is available, the Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC)+ 0%, plus a professional dispensing fee of $10.64
  • The Federal Upper Limit (FUL), plus a professional dispensing fee of $10.64
  • The provider’s Usual and Customary (U&C) charge to the general public regardless of program fees.

covered_entities.fdd:
Providers using 340B drugs for Medicaid patients are required to notify the Medicaid program as part of enrollment requirements.

Claims for drugs billed by 340B covered entities are excluded prior to rebate invoicing by the State’s rebate contractor using HRSA’s current covered entity list. Covered entities are required to provide the HRSA Office of Pharmacy Affairs with the Medicaid Provider Number/NPI used to bill Medicaid.

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic:
The lesser of:
  • The submitted actual acquisition covered outpatient drug cost
  • The federal upper limit established by CMS
  • The estimated acquisition cost
  • The state maximum allowable cost
covered_entities_340B.fdf:
Dispensing fees vary based on the location of the covered entity’s dispensing pharmacy:

  • for a pharmacy located on the road system, the dispensing fee is $13.36, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug;
  • for a pharmacy not located on the road system, the dispensing fee is $21.28, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug;
  • the dispensing fee for an out-of-state pharmacy is $10.76, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug;
  • the dispensing fee for a mediset pharmacy is $16.58, to be paid not more than once every 14 days per pharmacy percovered outpatient drug.

Medicaid will also pay the provider for reasonable and necessary postage or freight shipping, not to exceed $16, incurred in the delivery of the prescription from the dispensing pharmacy to the recipient if pharmacy services are not available in the recipient's community.
covered_entities_340B.fcd:
Actual Acquisition Cost covered outpatient drug cost is the unit cost that the facility pays for a drug, after subtracting all discounts. A facility may establish written protocols for establishing or calculating the facility's Actual Acquisition Cost for the drug based on a monthly, quarterly, or other average of the facility's Actual Acquisition Cost for the drug. A written protocol may not include an inflation, mark-up, spread, or margin to be added to the facility's actual purchase price after subtracting all discounts.


“Mediset pharmacy” means a pharmacy located in Alaska dispensing 75% or more of the total annual Medicaid prescriptions for covered outpatient drugs in prescriber-ordered medisets or unit doses to a recipient living in a congregate living home, a recipient of home- and community-based waiver services, a recipient eligible for Medicaid under a category set out in 7 AAC 100.002(b) or (d) who is blind or disabled, a recipient who is an adult experiencing a serious mental illness, or a recipient who is a child experiencing a severe emotional disturbance.

  • For a pharmacy not located on the road system, the dispensing fee is $21.28, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug.
  • The dispensing fee for an out-of-state pharmacy is $10.76, to be paid not more than once every 22 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug.
  • The dispensing fee for a mediset pharmacy is $16.58, to be paid not more than once every 14 days per pharmacy per covered outpatient drug.

Medicaid will also pay the provider for reasonable and necessary postage or freight shipping, not to exceed $16, incurred in the delivery of the prescription from the dispensing pharmacy to the recipient if pharmacy services are not available in the recipient’s community.

covered_entities.fdd:
An FQHC or FQHC Look-Alike shall:
Notify the AHCCCS provider registration unit of its status as a 340B covered entity no later than:
  • 30 days after February 1, 2012
  • 30 days after registration with the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) for participation in the 340B program, or
  • the time of application to become an AHCCCS provider.

    • The FQHC or Look-Alike shall also provide the 340B pricing file to the AHCCCS Administration upon request. The 340B pricing file shall be provided in the file format as defined by AHCCCS.

    The FQHC or Look-Alike shall also identify 340B drug claims submitted to the AHCCCS FFS PBM or the Managed Care Contractors' PBMs for reimbursement. The 340B drug claim identification and claims processing for a drug claim submission shall be consistent with claim instructions issued and required by AHCCCS to identify such claims.

covered_entities.fdd: Pharmacy providers who submit NCPDP claims to the Arkansas Medicaid Program on or after 10/1/2018 will be required to send value 07, 08 or 13 in the Basis of Cost Determination field (423-DN). Claims for prescriptions filled with medications purchased through the 340B program will carry the 08 value (340B Pricing) in the Basis of Cost Determination Field.

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic:
The 340B covered entity pharmacies that carve Medicaid into the 340B Drug Pricing Program will be reimbursed at the 340B Actual Invoice Price plus the established professional dispensing fee minus the beneficiary's copayment.

Reimbursement shall be no more than the 340B ceiling price.

The ceiling price will either be provided or can be calculated by Average Manufacturer Price (AMP) minus Unit Rebate Amount (URA)].

Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) that purchase drugs through the 340B program and carve in Medicaid will be reimbursed by the encounter rate except in the case of implantable contraceptive capsules, intrauterine devices and contraceptive injections in which case reimbursement will be no more than the 340B ceiling price.
covered_entities_340B.fdf:
Dispensing fee equals the average professional dispensing fee in the aggregate:

Brand and Non-preferred Brand = $9.00

Brand Preferred and Generic Medication drug = $10.50

covered_entities_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities  for non-340B drugs?
covered_entities_non-340B.fic:
The lesser of methodology is as follows:

For brand drugs:
  • The usual and customary charge to the public or submitted ingredient cost;or
  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC), as defined in B, plus the established professional dispensing fee;or
  • The ACA Federal Upper Limit (FUL) plus the established professional dispensing fee ;or
  • The calculated State Actual Acquisition Cost (SAAC), as defined in C, plus the established professional dispensing fee.
For generic drugs:
  • The usual and customary charge to the public or submitted ingredient cost; or
  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC), as defined in B, plus the established professional dispensing fee; or
  • The ACA Federal Upper Limit (FUL) plus the established professional dispensing fee; or
  • The calculated State Actual Acquisition Cost (SAAC), as defined in C, plus the established professional dispensing fee
Backup Ingredient Cost Benchmark

If NADAC is not available, the allowed ingredient cost, unless otherwise defined, shall be thelesser of Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) + 0%, State Actual Acquisition Cost (SAAC) or ACA Federal Upper Limit
covered_entities_non-340B.fdf:
Dispensing fee equals the average professional dispensing fee in the aggregate:

Brand and Non-preferred Brand = $9.00

Brand Preferred and Generic Medication drug = $10.50

covered_entities_340B.fic: The entity’s Actual Acquisition Cost for the drug, as charged by the manufacturer
covered_entities_340B.fdf:
Varies based on the previous year’s annual claim volume (both Medicaid and non-Medicaid) as follows:

  • Fewer than 90,000 claims per year: $13.20
  • 90,000 or more claims per year: $10.05
covered_entities_340B.fcd:
Pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 14132.01, qualifying clinics are eligible for clinic dispensing fees not to exceed $12 per prescription, unless the drug is a take-home drug that is dispensed for use by the patient within a specific timeframe of five or less days from the date medically indicated, in which case the clinic dispensing fee is not to exceed $17 per prescription.

For physician administered drugs (PADs), the maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for immunizations shall be $9.00. The maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for other injections shall be $4.46.

The entity’s Actual Acquisition Cost for the drug, as
charged by the manufacturer

Varies based on the previous year’s annual claim volume (both Medicaid and nonMedicaid), as follows:

  • Fewer than 90,000 claims per year: $13.20
  • 90,000 or more claims per year: $10.05
contract_pharmacies_340B.fdd: A contract pharmacy, under contract with a 340B covered entity may only use 340B drugs to dispense Medicaid prescriptions if the covered entity, the contract pharmacy, and the State Medicaid agency have established an arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts and the details of that arrangement have been shared with HRSA.

covered_entities_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities  for non-340B drugs?
covered_entities_non-340B.fic:
Payment for legend and non-legend covered outpatient drugs not dispensed by a retail community pharmacy (i.e., dispensed by an institutional or long-term care facility pharmacy) shall be the lower of the drug’s ingredient cost plus a professional dispensing fee, or the pharmacy’s usual and customary charge to the public.

The “drug’s ingredient cost” means the lowest of:
  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) (which will be replaced with the Wholesaler Acquisition Cost (WAC) when no NADAC is available);
  • Federal upper limit (FUL); or
  • Maximum allowable ingredient cost (MAIC)

PADs are the lower of the usual and customary charge or the Medicare Part B reimbursement rate plus the professional services for immunizations/injections.
covered_entities_non-340B.fdf:
The dispensing fee varies based on the previous year’s annual claim volume (both Medicaid and non-Medicaid) as follows:

  • Fewer than 90,000 claims per year: $13.20
  • 90,000 or more claims per year: $10.05
covered_entities_non-340B.fcd: The maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for immunizations shall be $9.00. The maximum reimbursement rate for professional services for other injections shall be $4.46.

contract_pharmacies_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse 340B contract pharmacies for non-340B drugs?
contract_pharmacies_non-340B.fic:
Payment for legend and non-legend covered outpatient drugs not dispensed by a retail community pharmacy (i.e. institutional or long-term care facility pharmacies) shall be the lower of the drug’s ingredient cost plus a professional dispensing fee, or the pharmacy’s usual and customary charge to the public.

The “drug’s ingredient cost” means the lowest of:
  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) (which will be replaced with the Wholesaler Acquisition Cost (WAC) when no NADAC is available),
  • Federal upper limit (FUL),
  • Maximum allowable ingredient cost (MAIC)

PADs are the lower of the usual and customary charge or the Medicare Part B reimbursement rate plus the professional services for immunizations/injections
contract_pharmacies_non-340B.fdf:
The dispensing fee varies based on the previous year’s annual claim volume (both Medicaid and non-Medicaid) as follows:

  • Less than 90,000 claims per year: $13.20
  • 90,000 or more claims per year: $10.05
contract_pharmacies_non-340B.fdd: A contract pharmacy, under contract with a 340B covered entity may only use 340B drugs to dispense Medicaid prescriptions if the covered entity, the contract pharmacy, and the State Medicaid agency have established an arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts and the details of that arrangement have been shared with HRSA.

covered_entities.mdd:
Unless a covered entity, its contracted pharmacies and the state Medicaid agency have established an arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts, the covered entity and its contracted pharmacies are prohibited from using drugs purchased under the 340B program to be dispensed to Medicaid members. In addition, the covered entity must report any arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts to HRSA. DHCS incorporated this requirement into the California Medicaid State Plan for the Medi-Cal program (FFS and managed care) via State Plan Amendment 17-002.

The terms of the required arrangement must be formalized in the MCO’s policies and procedures and approved by DHCS, prior to the MCO allowing or initiating a 340B contract pharmacy arrangement within its provider network.

contract_pharmacies.mdd:
Unless a covered entity, its contracted pharmacies and the state Medicaid agency have established an arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts, the covered entity and its contracted pharmacies are prohibited from using drugs purchased under the 340B program to be dispensed to Medicaid members. In addition, the covered entity must report any arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts to HRSA. DHCS incorporated this requirement into the California Medicaid State Plan for the Medi-Cal program (FFS and managed care) via State Plan Amendment 17-002.

The terms of the required arrangement must be formalized in the MCO’s policies and procedures and approved by DHCS, prior to the MCO allowing or initiating a 340B contract pharmacy arrangement within its provider network.

contract_pharmacies_non-340B.mcd:
California MCO model contracts do not instruct the MCOs with regard to payment amounts with their vendors.

Covered entities should contact their respective MCO for clarification on billing, reimbursement, and claim identification requirements for both the covered entity and their contract pharmacies.
contract_pharmacies_non-340B.mdd:
Unless a covered entity, its contracted pharmacies and the state Medicaid agency have established an arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts, the covered entity and its contracted pharmacies are prohibited from using drugs purchased under the 340B program to be dispensed to Medicaid members. In addition, the covered entity must report any arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts to HRSA. DHCS incorporated this requirement into the California Medicaid State Plan for the Medi-Cal program (FFS and managed care) via State Plan Amendment 17-002.

The terms of the required arrangement must be formalized in the MCO’s policies and procedures and approved by DHCS, prior to the MCO allowing or initiating a 340B contract pharmacy arrangement within its provider network.

covered_entities.fdd:
Covered entities who carve-in must have their NPI number listed on HRSA’s Medicaid Exclusion File.

In addition, effective June 1, 2017, 340B claims submitted via the National Council for Prescription Drug Programs (NCPDP) D.0 format must include the following:

  • Value of “20” in field 420-DK, Submission Clarification Code; and
  • Value of “08” or “05” in field 423-DN, Basis of Cost Determination.

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?

The lower of:
  • The usual and customary charge to the public; or
  • The allowed ingredient cost plus a professional dispensing fee.
covered_entities_340B.fdf: The same as for 340B drugs.
covered_entities_340B.fcd:
The allowed ingredient cost is the lesser of Colorado Actual Acquisition Cost (AAC) or submitted ingredient cost. If AAC is not available the allowed ingredient cost is the lesser of Wholesale Acquisition Cost or submitted ingredient cost.

The Department shall update AAC on a regular basis based on changes in pharmacies' acquisition costs and national pricing benchmarks such as WAC. The AAC price list is available through the Department' s website (colorado.gov/hcpf)

contract_pharmacies.fdd: Pharmacies must enroll under a separate NPI to bill 340B drugs. All drugs billed under the 340B enrolled NPI are excluded from drug rebate. During the enrollment process, the NPI submitted is verified against the HRSA 340B entity file.

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic:
Brand name single source and multisource drugs will reimburse at the Brand NADAC price while generic drugs will reimburse at the Generic NADAC price. Claims for drugs without a NADAC price will reimburse at the lesser of the Federal Upper Limit (FUL) or the Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) with the following exceptions, which will always reimburse at WAC:

  • Preferred brand name medications (as identified on the Preferred Drug List (PDL), and
  • medications submitted with a Dispense as Written Code of “1” (Substitution Not Allowed-Brand Medically Necessary), for all HUSKY A, HUSKY C, HUSKY D, TB AND FAMPL recipients.
covered_entities_340B.fcd: Dispensing fees are only paid on reimbursable pharmacy claims submitted with a National Drug Code (NDC) of a legend drug.

Pharmacy providers submitting claims through the point-of-sale system for drugs purchased through the 340B program must identify the drug as a 340B-purchased drug by populating the Submission Clarification Code (420-DK) field with a value of “20.” Providers are required to add the dispensing fee to the provider charge.

The provider shall support all Department-based efforts and initiatives for 340B claim identification at a claim level of detail, including the utilization of the NCPDP fields designed for this purpose. Providers must require pharmacy providers or processing vendors to identify 340B purchased drugs on claims.

contract_pharmacies.mdd:
The state has advised that contract pharmacies may not submit claims to Medicaid MCO for 340B-acquired drugs, unless there is an agreement in place with the State, the covered entity, and the contract pharmacy. This covered entity must report this agreement to HRSA.

In addition, the Kentucky Medicaid Managed Care Master Agreement states that the provider shall support all Department-based efforts and initiatives for 340B claim identification at a claim level of detail, including the utilization of the NCPDP fields designed for this purpose. Provider must require pharmacy providers or processing vendors to identify 340B purchased drugs on claims.

covered_entities.fdd: Providers must indicate drugs purchased through the 340B program using the modifier "U6" for institutional and professional claims, and enter the value "20" in the Submission Clarification Code field for pharmacy claims. Additionally, hospitals paid under OPPS that are not excepted from340B drug payment policy are required to report modifier “JG” on the same claim line as the drug HCPCS code to identify a 340B-acquired drug.

contract_pharmacies.fdd: Contract pharmacies must indicate on the claim that the drug was purchased through the 340B program so their claims can be excluded from the drug rebates. Pharmacy claims for outpatient drugs purchased through the 340B program must be indicated on the claim using a Submission Clarification Code of “20”.

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic: Actual Acquisition Cost (AAC).
covered_entities_340B.fdf:
• $10.64 for drugs not on the preferred drug list (PDL)
  • $10.80 for drugs indicated as preferred on the PDL
  • $9.00 for drugs indicated as non-preferred on the PDL
  • $20.02 for specialty drugs
covered_entities_340B.fcd: Exception: hospitals have the option to have their 340B drug costs adjusted from AAC to normal and customary charge for the purpose of hospital final settlement process only (even in this case, the provider must bill AAC).

contract_pharmacies_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse 340B contract pharmacies for 340B drugs?
contract_pharmacies_340B.fdf:
• $10.64 for drugs not on the PDL
  • $10.80 for drugs indicated as preferred on the PDL
  • $9.00 for drugs indicated as non-preferred on the PDL
  • $20.02 for specialty drugs
contract_pharmacies_340B.fcd: Drugs purchased through the 340B program and dispensed by 340B contract pharmacies will not be reimbursed by the state unless the covered entity, the contract pharmacy and the department have established an arrangement to prevent duplicate discounts.
contract_pharmacies_340B.fdd: Contract pharmacies must indicate on the claim that the drug was purchased through the 340B program so their claims can be excluded from the drug rebates. Pharmacy claims for outpatient drugs purchased through the 340B program must be indicated on the claim using a Submission Clarification Code of “20”.

covered_entities_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities  for non-340B drugs?
covered_entities_non-340B.fic:
Outpatient drug reimbursement is based on lower of:
  • AAC plus dispensing fee;
  • WAC plus dispensing fee;
  • MAC plus dispensing fee; or
  • Provider’s charge.
covered_entities_non-340B.fdf:
• $10.64 for drugs not on the PDL
  • $10.80 for drugs indicated as preferred on the PDL
  • $9.00 for drugs indicated as non-preferred on the PDL
  • $20.02 for specialty drugs
covered_entities_non-340B.fcd: N/A

covered_entities.fdd: Covered entities must either use 340B drugs for all Medicaid recipients (fee-for-service and managed care) or not use 340B drugs for any Medicaid recipients (fee-for-service and managed care). Minnesota uses the HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File to determine which approach covered entities take. Covered entities must also submit the Submission Clarification Code “20” or UD modifier on the claim or claim lines.

contract_pharmacies.fdd: N/A.  Contract pharmacies may not bill Medicaid for 340B-purchased drugs.

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic: The ingredient cost for 340B drugs is either the 340B Drug Pricing Program ceiling price established by the Health Resources and Services Administration or the National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC), whichever is lower.
covered_entities_340B.fcd: N/A

contract_pharmacies_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse 340B contract pharmacies for 340B drugs?
contract_pharmacies_340B.fic: N/A (unless the contract pharmacy is owned by a 340B entity, in which case the rules above apply).
contract_pharmacies_340B.fcd: Contract pharmacies may not bill Medicaid for 340B-purchased drugs unless the contract pharmacy is owned by a 340B covered entity.
contract_pharmacies_340B.fdd: N/A.  Contract pharmacies may not bill Medicaid for 340B-purchased drugs.

covered_entities_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities  for non-340B drugs?
covered_entities_non-340B.fic: The amount of payment is the lower of the ingredient costs of the drugs plus the professional dispensing fee, or the usual and customary price charged to the public. The usual and customary price means the lowest price charged by the provider to a patient who pays for the prescription by cash, check or charge account and includes prices the pharmacy charges to a patient enrolled in a prescription savings club or prescription discount club administered by the pharmacy or pharmacy chain. NADAC or the State Maximum Allowable Cost (SMAC) is used to determine the ingredient cost of a drug.
covered_entities_non-340B.fcd: The amount of payment basis must be reduced to reflect all discount amounts applied to the charge by any third-party provider/insurer agreement or contract for submitted charges to medical assistance programs. The net submitted charge may not be greater than the patient liability for the service.

contract_pharmacies_non-340B.fdd: N/A.  Contract pharmacies may not bill Medicaid for 340B-purchased drugs.

In addition, providers must bill the appropriate code(s) on a claim billed with a 340B-purchased drug. A “UD” modifier is required for physician-administered drug claims, while pharmacy claims require the inclusion of both “08” in field 423-DN (the Basis of Cost Determination field) and “20” in field 420-DK (the Submission Clarification Code field).

covered_entities_non-340B.fic:
The lowest of:

  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) plus a professional dispensing fee of $11.29
  • The Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) plus zero percent (0%) plus a professional dispensing fee of $11.29 when no NADAC is available
  • A rate set by the Division of Medicaid’s rate-setting vendor plus a professional dispensing fee of $11.29 when no NADAC or WAC are available
  • The provider’s usual and customary charge

covered_entities_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities  for non-340B drugs?
covered_entities_non-340B.fic:
Reimbursement is the lowest of:
  • Federal Upper Limit (FUL) plus dispensing fee
  • If there is no FUL, Missouri Maximum Allowed Cost (MAC), plus dispensing fee
  • If no FUL or MAC, Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) minus 3.1%, plus dispensing fee
  • Usual and Customary charge (U&C) submitted by the provider IF it is lower than the chosen price (FUL, MAC, or WAC).
covered_entities_non-340B.fdf:
• Base: $9.5
  • In-state providers receive enhancement of $4.82
  • Enhanced preferred generic product incentive: $5.00 (in-state pharmacies only)
covered_entities_non-340B.fcd: Dispensing fee is only available to pharmacy providers. RHCs, FQHCs, and hospital providers are reimbursed at percent of billed charge.

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic:
The lower of:

  • Usual and customary charge to the general public
  • The allowed ingredient cost* plus a dispensing fee

Allowed ingredient cost* is the lowest of:

  • Average Acquisition Cost (AAC)
  • Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC)
  • Federal Upper Limit (FUL)
  • Submitted ingredient cost (for 340B drugs, submitted ingredient cost means the actual 340B purchase price)
covered_entities_340B.fdf:
The dispensing fee assigned shall range between:
  • The minimum of $2.32 and the maximum of $15.14 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume between 0 and 39,999
  • The minimum of $2.32 and the maximum of $13.12 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume between 40,000 and 69,999
  • The minimum is $2.32 and the maximum is $11.10 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume greater than 70,000.

*Allowed ingredient cost is the lowest of:

  • AAC
  • WAC
  • FUL
  • Submitted ingredient cost (for 340B drugs, submitted ingredient cost means the actual 340B purchase price)
contract_pharmacies_340B.fdf:
The dispensing fee assigned shall range between:
  • The minimum of $2.32 and the maximum of $15.14 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume between 0 and 39,999
  • The minimum of $2.32 and the maximum of $13.12 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume between 40,000 and 69,999
  • The minimum is $2.32 and the maximum is $11.10 for pharmacies with an annual prescription volume greater than 70,000.

  • The National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) plus the established professional dispensing fee

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic: Actual Acquisition Cost (AAC)
covered_entities_340B.fcd:
AAC means the actual prices paid by a pharmacy to acquire drug products marketed or sold by manufacturers. The maximum allowable ingredient drug cost, calculated based on an AAC, is defined as the lowest of:

• National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) or in the absence of a NADAC price, Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) less 2%
• The Federal Upper Limit (FUL) price for covered outpatient drugs
• The State Upper Limit (SUL) price for covered outpatient drugs (calculated as 100% of drug acquisition costs for covered outpatient drugs as determined by state-sponsored pharmacy surveys)
• The 340B Drug Discount Program ceiling price, or in the absence of a 340B ceiling price, WAC less 25%
• A pharmacy’s usual and customary charge.

• The 340B Drug Discount Program ceiling price, or in the absence of a 340B ceiling price, WAC less 25%
• A pharmacy’s usual and customary charge.

covered_entities.fdd:
The HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File. Covered entities are required to report any changes to the Oklahoma Health Care Authority (OHCA) within 30 days.

To prevent a duplicate discount, quarterly adjustments will be made to all pharmacy or medical claims for drugs submitted by the covered entity. OHCA will adjust each claim by subtracting the 340B ceiling price from the amount reimbursed and multiplying the difference by the quantity submitted. All drugs shall be adjusted by the 340B ceiling price whether purchased through the 340B program or otherwise when billed using the registered SoonerCare NPI number on the HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File.

HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File:

“Covered entities that will carve-in are required to inform HRSA (by providing their Medicaid provider number/NPI) at the time they enroll in the 340B Program that they will purchase and dispense 340B drugs for their Medicaid patients. If covered entities decide to bill to Medicaid for 340B-purchased drugs with a Medicaid provider number/NPI, then ALL [fee-for-service and Coordinated Care Organization] drugs billed to that number must be purchased under 340B and that Medicaid provider number/NPI must be listed on the HRSA Medicaid Exclusion File.”

covered_entities.fdd:
Covered entities participating in the 340B program are required to identify in the proper field of the Texas Medicaid Pharmacy Provider Enrollment application that they are eligible to purchase products under the 340B program

Covered entities participating in the 340B program must use modifier “U8” when submitting claims for 340B clinician-administered drugs.

In addition, pharmacies of eligible entities participating in the 340B Program must identify all outpatient pharmacy claims filled with 340B drugs by submitting a value of "20" ("340B / Disproportionate Share Pricing/Public Health Service") in the Submission Clarification Code field (420-DK)"

contract_pharmacies.fdd: Pharmacies of eligible entities participating in the 340B program must identify all outpatient pharmacy claims filled with 340B drugs by submitting a value of “20” (340B/Disproportionate Share Pricing/Public Health Service) in the Submission Clarification Code field (420-DK)

covered_entities_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities for 340B drugs?
covered_entities_340B.fic:
• Brands and generics: Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) minus 57%
  • Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) products: WAC minus 40%
  • Hemophilia products: WAC minus 32%
covered_entities_340B.fdf: $7.93 plus a variable component that is based on the drug’s ingredient cost plus $0.50 for premium preferred generic drugs (other than $0 total payment amount claims).
covered_entities_340B.fcd: New drugs are added to the formulary at WAC minus 23.1% for 6 months. This methodology is not all-inclusive and some products may be priced manually.

contract_pharmacies_340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse 340B contract pharmacies for 340B drugs?
contract_pharmacies_340B.fic:
• Brands and generics: WAC minus 57%
  • HIV products: WAC minus 40%
  • Hemophilia products: WAC minus 32%
contract_pharmacies_340B.fdf: $7.93 plus a variable component that is based on the drug’s ingredient cost plus $0.50 for premium preferred generic drugs (other than $0 total payment amount claims).
contract_pharmacies_340B.fcd: New drugs are added to the formulary at WAC minus 23.1 percent for 6 months. This methodology is not all-inclusive and some products may be priced manually.
contract_pharmacies_340B.fdd: Pharmacies of eligible entities participating in the 340B program must identify all outpatient pharmacy claims filled with 340B drugs by submitting a value of “20” (340B/Disproportionate Share Pricing/Public Health Service) in the Submission Clarification Code field (420-DK)

covered_entities_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse covered entities  for non-340B drugs?
covered_entities_non-340B.fic:
Ingredient costs of legend and nonlegend drugs:

  • Retail pharmacy: National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC)
  • Long-term care (LTC) pharmacy: NADAC minus 2.4%
  • Specialty pharmacy: NADAC minus 1.7%

If NADAC is not available for a specific drug:

  • Retail pharmacy: WAC minus 2%
  • LTC pharmacy: WAC minus 3.4%
  • Specialty pharmacy: WAC minus 8%
covered_entities_non-340B.fdf: $7.93 plus a variable component that is based on the drug’s ingredient cost plus $0.15 delivery incentive for legend drugs plus $0.50 for premium preferred generic drugs (other than $0 total payment amount claims).

contract_pharmacies_non-340B.que: How much does the state Medicaid program reimburse 340B contract pharmacies for non-340B drugs?
contract_pharmacies_non-340B.fic:
• Brands and generics: WAC minus 57%
  • HIV products: WAC minus 40%
  • Hemophilia products: WAC minus 32%
contract_pharmacies_non-340B.fdf: $7.93 plus a variable component that is based on the drug’s ingredient cost plus $0.15 delivery incentive for legend drugs plus $0.50 for premium preferred generic drugs (other than $0 total payment amount claims)
contract_pharmacies_non-340B.fdd: Pharmacies of eligible entities participating in the 340B program must identify all outpatient pharmacy claims filled with 340B drugs by submitting a value of “20” (340B/Disproportionate Share Pricing/Public Health Service) in the Submission Clarification Code field (420-DK)

covered_entities.mdd: Medicaid managed care health plans have been notified of the eligible entity's requirement to submit a value of “20” in the Submission Clarification Code field (420-DK) for pharmacy claims to denote claims filled with stock purchased through the 340B program.

covered_entities.fdd:
All claims submitted to Utah Medicaid from a 340B covered entity for medications that were purchased through the 340B program must be submitted:

  1. For point-of-sale claims, this is indicated by using Submission Clarification Code "20" and Basis of Cost "8".
  2. For provider administered claims, this is indicated by adding the “UD” modifier to the claim.
  3. For provider-administered Medicare crossover claims, this is indicated by adding the “JG” or “TB” modifiers.

covered_entities.fdd:
There are two processes in place. Initially, all NPIs for covered entities enrolled in the Medicaid 340B program are excluded from rebate processing. Subsequently, a manual reconciliation process occurs whereby the covered entity is provided a paid claims file for the previous month. The covered entity is asked to validate the drugs that are 340B, and provide their 340B acquisition cost (AC). A financial settlement occurs to ensure that Medicaid receives the AC. Anything identified by the covered entity as non-340B eligible is then included for rebate processing.

Alternatively, a pharmacy may submit the 340B AC on the claim using the proper NCPDP submission codes (Submission Clarification Code “20” and Basis of Cost Determination “08”) for a 340B claim. All claims with 340B identifiers are excluded from rebate processing.

covered_entities_340B.fcd:
340B AAC: The true cost paid by a public health service-qualifying entity for a specific drug, excluding dispensing fees.

Exceptions to the 340B AAC billing requirement are only made for:


• Outpatient hospital claims paid under the enhanced ambulatory payment group methodology (see Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC) 182-550-7000) and
• Ambulatory surgery claims paid under payment groups methodology

covered_entities.fdd:
Medical providers billing West Virginia Medicaid for 340B outpatient drugs should submit modifier "UD" with the HCPCS drug code to identify drugs purchased at 340B prices. All 340B pharmacy providers for West Virginia Medicaid are required to bill each pharmacy point-of-sale claim with the following NCPDP values: claim segment - Submission Clarification Code (420-DK), use value "20" in Position 1 or 2.

Pricing segment – Basis of Cost Determination (423-DN), use value “08.”

covered_entities.mdd: As noted above, outpatient pharmacy point-of-sale drugs are carved out of the MCO contract. For physician-administered drugs, each pharmacy and medical encounter must include a 340B indicator, supplied by the provider at the time of billing, verifying whether or not a 340B drug was dispensed/administered to the Medicaid member. The MCO shall report this information using a standardized template supplied by the Department. The MCO must validate their 340B drug cost claims data by confirming that drug costs for 340B-prescribed drugs do not exceed non-340B costs for the same drug and provide quarterly attestation that the verification has been completed.
